bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg discusses plans for an unveiling of the Cuban version of the Cornwell painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1942
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
March 4, 1942.
AIR MAIL
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am much pleased to get your letter of the 26th and I am interested
in what you say about the continuous search for new material on
yellow fever.

I have just talked with Mr. Hodgman regarding the possibility of a
meeting and unveiling of the painting in Cuba. He says that the
Cuban Medical Society (or whatever they call the organization) does
not have regularly scheduled national meetings, that they had none
last year and therefore it is anticipated that they will have one
this year but possibly not until late fall. He is in close touch
with Dr. Kohley, editor of the medical journal, as well as our Cuban
distributors who have agreed to notify him as soon as any announce-
ment of a meeting is made.

Mr. Hodgman says that if they do have such a meeting we would de-
finitely wish to make it. In the light of the foregoing, however,
I would hesitate to suggest that you make any change in the vacation
plans as you might find yourself merely inconvenienced for nothing.
One of the bad features of the situation is that they do not announce
their meerings more than a couple of months ahead.

As to Dr. Hoffmann, I am sure that all he wants is prints of the paint-
ing and not your reprints which I believe he probably has not seen.
We have actually sent him only fifty of these as we found that we
have a shortage. If we go back to press with the inserts we will
send him a reasonable quantity if he wants them.

I am sending you five reproductions of the Cuban versions. I hope
that you will be able to use the colored plates themselves at some
time in the future.

Two weeks ago TIME magazine called and they wanted photographs and
key of the “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” for last week's issue. How-
ever, when the magazine came out they had only used an old Florence
Nightingale print. I suppose they ran short of space.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester,
Minnesota
